customer_name: Richard L Miller D V M, P A
site_name: Richard L Miller D V M, P A

citations.narrative:
Multiple primary outdoor enclosures housing capuchins contained rusted wire paneling and chains that showed signs of
wear and/or degradation. Additionally, two enclosures housing six ring-tailed lemurs contained rusted wire paneling at the
bottom of both enclosures. Rusted primary enclosure materials can lose structural integrity over time and cannot be
properly cleaned and sanitized. Excessively rusty surfaces that animals have daily contact with can be injurious to the
animals and make the sanitization process difficult. The licensee must ensure that any surfaces that come into contact
with non-human primates are free of excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitization, or that affects the
structural strength of the surface.

A primary enclosure housing six Linnaeus's two-toed sloths had two large mounds of excreta on the bottom of the
enclosure. The licensee admitted that excreta had not recently been removed from this enclosure due to an employee
recently quitting. Additionally, a primary enclosure housing a Tayra had an excessive amount of excreta on the top of a
barrel. These excessive accumulations of excreta could facilitate disease transmission to the animals. Excreta must be
removed as often as necessary to minimize disease hazards.

The facility does not have adequate housekeeping for the premises. There were accumulations of discarded and unused
items present throughout the premises including wire cages, plywood, construction materials, empty feed bags, plastic
containers, wooden pallets, wire paneling, animal crates, and clay roofing tiles. Overgrown weeds were also noted among
these discarded, unused items. Accumulations of debris can provide areas which can harbor disease-transmitting pests
and could increase health risks to the animals.
Premises (buildings and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury and to
facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. Accumulations of trash shall be placed in designated
areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health of the animals.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by September 26, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License
Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
KRISTIN NAPOLI n

narrative:
3.75(c)(1)(i) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Multiple primary outdoor enclosures housing capuchins contained rusted wire paneling and chains that showed signs of 
wear and/or degradation. Additionally, two enclosures housing six ring-tailed lemurs contained rusted wire paneling at the 
bottom of both enclosures. Rusted primary enclosure materials can lose structural integrity over time and cannot be 
properly cleaned and sanitized. Excessively rusty surfaces that animals have daily contact with can be injurious to the 
animals and make the sanitization process difficult. The licensee must ensure that any surfaces that come into contact 
with non-human primates are free of excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitization, or that affects the 
structural strength of the surface. 
3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation. 
A primary enclosure housing six Linnaeus's two-toed sloths had two large mounds of excreta on the bottom of the 
enclosure. The licensee admitted that excreta had not recently been removed from this enclosure due to an employee 
recently quitting. Additionally, a primary enclosure housing a Tayra had an excessive amount of excreta on the top of a 
barrel. These excessive accumulations of excreta could facilitate disease transmission to the animals. Excreta must be 
removed as often as necessary to minimize disease hazards. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
The facility does not have adequate housekeeping for the premises. There were accumulations of discarded and unused 
items present throughout the premises including wire cages, plywood, construction materials, empty feed bags, plastic 
containers, wooden pallets, wire paneling, animal crates, and clay roofing tiles. Overgrown weeds were also noted among 
these discarded, unused items. Accumulations of debris can provide areas which can harbor disease-transmitting pests 
and could increase health risks to the animals. 
 
Premises (buildings and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury and to 
facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. Accumulations of trash shall be placed in designated 
areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health of the animals.

This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by September 26, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the 
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License 
Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
Additional Inspectors:
